standard_metadata.standard_description: Find whole-number quotients of whole numbers with up to four-digit dividends and two-digit divisors, using strategies based on place value, the properties of operations, and/or the relationship between multiplication and division. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.

hints.content: To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $\maroonD{31}$ that may be useful:  - $\maroonD{31} \times 1 = 31$ - $\maroonD{31} \times 2 = 62$ - $\maroonD{31} \times 5 = 155$
$\maroonD{31} \times 20 $ is a little too large.    So, let's start by dividing $589$ into $\purpleD{10}\maroonD{\text{ thirty-ones}}$.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{31}&\overline{\Big)589}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{310}}&\purpleD{10}&\maroonD{31} \times \purpleD{10} = \blueE{310}\\ &279\\ \end{array}$  We have $279$ left. That's a little less than $310$. So, let's try dividing $279$ into $9\maroonD{\text{ thirty-ones}}$.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{31}&\overline{\Big)589}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{310}&10\\ &279\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{279}}&\purpleD{9}&\maroonD{31} \times \purpleD{9} = \blueE{279}\\ &0\\ \end{array}$

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} {31}&\overline{\Big)589}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{310}&\purpleD{10}\\ &279\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{279}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{9}}\\ &\goldE{0}&\greenE{19}\\ \end{array}$  $\purpleD{10} + \purpleD{9}= \greenE{19}$, so our quotient is $\greenE{19}$, and we have no remainder.
$589 \div 31=\greenE{19}\text{ remainder }\goldE{0}$  [[☃ explanation 1]]

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $\maroonD{20}$ that may be useful:  - $\maroonD{20} \times 2 = 40$ - $\maroonD{20} \times 3 = 60$ - $\maroonD{20} \times 4 = 80$
$\maroonD{20} \times 40 $ is a little too large.    So, let's start by dividing $740$ into $\purpleD{30}\maroonD{\text{ twenties}}$.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{20}&\overline{\Big)740}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{600}}&\purpleD{30}&\maroonD{20} \times \purpleD{30} = \blueE{600}\\ &140\\ \end{array}$  We have $140$ left. We know that $7 \times 2=14$. So, let's try dividing $140$ into $7\maroonD{\text{ twenties}}$.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{20}&\overline{\Big)740}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{600}&30\\ &140\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{140}}&\purpleD{7}&\maroonD{20} \times \purpleD{7} = \blueE{140}\\ &0\\ \end{array}$

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} {20}&\overline{\Big)740}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{600}&\purpleD{30}\\ &140\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{140}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{7}}\\ &\goldE{0}&\greenE{37}\\ \end{array}$  $\purpleD{30} + \purpleD{7}= \greenE{37}$, so our quotient is $\greenE{37}$, and we have no remainder.
|| -: | :- $\greenE{37}$ | remainder $\goldE{0}$ ${20}\overline{\Big)740}$ |  [[☃ explanation 1]]

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $\maroonD{19}$ that may be useful:  - $\maroonD{19} \times 2 = 38$ - $\maroonD{19} \times 4 = 76$ - $\maroonD{19} \times 5 = 95$
$\maroonD{19} \times 40$ is close.    So, let's start by dividing $798$ into $\purpleD{40}\maroonD{\text{ nineteens}}$.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{19}&\overline{\Big)798}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{760}}&\purpleD{40}&\maroonD{19} \times \purpleD{40} = \blueE{760}\\ &38\\ \end{array}$  We have $38$ left. We know that $19 \times 2=38$. So, let's try dividing $38$ into $2\maroonD{\text{ nineteens}}$.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{19}&\overline{\Big)798}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{760}&40\\ &38\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{38}}&\purpleD{2}&\maroonD{19} \times \purpleD{2} = \blueE{38}\\ &0\\ \end{array}$

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} {19}&\overline{\Big)798}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{760}&\purpleD{40}\\ &38\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{38}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{2}}\\ &\goldE{0}&\greenE{42}\\ \end{array}$  $\purpleD{40} + \purpleD{2}= \greenE{42}$, so our quotient is $\greenE{42}$, and we have no remainder.
$798 \div 19=\greenE{42}\text{ remainder }\goldE{0}$  [[☃ explanation 1]]

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $\maroonD{45}$ that may be useful:  - $\maroonD{45} \times 1 = 45$ - $\maroonD{45} \times 2 = 90$ - $\maroonD{45} \times 4 = 180$
$\maroonD{45} \times 20 $ is a little too large.    So, let's start by dividing $855$ into $\purpleD{10}\maroonD{\text{ forty-fives}}$.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{45}&\overline{\Big)855}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{450}}&\purpleD{10}&\maroonD{45} \times \purpleD{10} = \blueE{450}\\ &405\\ \end{array}$  We have $405$ left. That's a little less than $450$. So, let's try dividing $405$ into $9\maroonD{\text{ forty-fives}}$.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{45}&\overline{\Big)855}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{450}&10\\ &405\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{405}}&\purpleD{9}&\maroonD{45} \times \purpleD{9} = \blueE{405}\\ &0\\ \end{array}$

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} {45}&\overline{\Big)855}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{450}&\purpleD{10}\\ &405\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{405}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{9}}\\ &\goldE{0}&\greenE{19}\\ \end{array}$  $\purpleD{10} + \purpleD{9}= \greenE{19}$, so our quotient is $\greenE{19}$, and we have no remainder.
|| -: | :- $\greenE{19}$ | remainder $\goldE{0}$ ${45}\overline{\Big)855}$ |  [[☃ explanation 1]]

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $\maroonD{35}$ that may be useful:  - $\maroonD{35} \times 2 = 70$ - $\maroonD{35} \times 3 = 105$ - $\maroonD{35} \times 6 = 210$
$\maroonD{35} \times 30$ is a little too large.    So, let's start by dividing $945$ into $\purpleD{20}\maroonD{\text{ thirty-fives}}$.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{35}&\overline{\Big)945}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{700}}&\purpleD{20}&\maroonD{35} \times \purpleD{20} = \blueE{700}\\ &245\\ \end{array}$  We have $245$ left. That's a little more than $210$. So, let's try dividing $245$ into $7\maroonD{\text{ thirty-fives}}$.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{35}&\overline{\Big)945}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{700}&20\\ &245\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{245}}&\purpleD{7}&\maroonD{35} \times \purpleD{7} = \blueE{245}\\ &0\\ \end{array}$

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} {35}&\overline{\Big)945}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{700}&\purpleD{20}\\ &245\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{245}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{7}}\\ &\goldE{0}&\greenE{27}\\ \end{array}$  $\purpleD{20} + \purpleD{7}= \greenE{27}$, so our quotient is $\greenE{27}$, and we have no remainder.
$945 \div 35=\greenE{27}\text{ remainder }\goldE{0}$  [[☃ explanation 1]]

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $\maroonD{14}$ that may be useful:  - $\maroonD{14} \times 2 = 28$ - $\maroonD{14} \times 3 = 42$ - $\maroonD{14} \times 5 = 70$
$\maroonD{14} \times 30 $ is a little too large.    So, let's start by dividing $374$ into $\purpleD{20}\maroonD{\text{ fourteens}}$.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{14}&\overline{\Big)374}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{280}}&\purpleD{20}&\maroonD{14} \times \purpleD{20} = \blueE{280}\\ &94\\ \end{array}$  We have $94$ left. That's a little more than $80$. So, let's try dividing $94$ into $6\maroonD{\text{ fourteens}}$.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{14}&\overline{\Big)374}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{280}&20\\ &94\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{84}}&\purpleD{6}&\maroonD{14} \times \purpleD{6} = \blueE{84}\\ &10\\ \end{array}$  We have $10$ left. That's less than $\maroonD{14}$, so we're done dividing.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} {14}&\overline{\Big)374}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{280}&\purpleD{20}\\ &94\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{84}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{6}}\\ &\goldE{10}&\greenE{26}\\ \end{array}$  $\purpleD{20} + \purpleD{6}= \greenE{26}$, so our quotient is $\greenE{26}$, and our remainder is $\goldE{10}$.
|| -: | :- $\greenE{26}$ | remainder $\goldE{10}$ ${14}\overline{\Big)374}$ |  [[☃ explanation 1]]

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $\maroonD{27}$ that may be useful:  - $\maroonD{27} \times 1 = 27$ - $\maroonD{27} \times 2 = 54$ - $\maroonD{27} \times 5 = 135$
$\maroonD{27} \times 20 $ is a little too large.    So, let's start by dividing $421$ into $\purpleD{10}\maroonD{\text{ twenty-sevens}}$.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{27}&\overline{\Big)421}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{270}}&\purpleD{10}&\maroonD{27} \times \purpleD{10} = \blueE{270}\\ &151\\ \end{array}$  We have $151$ left. That's a little more than $135$. So, let's try dividing $151$ into $5\maroonD{\text{ twenty-sevens}}$.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{27}&\overline{\Big)421}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{270}&10\\ &151\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{135}}&\purpleD{5}&\maroonD{27} \times \purpleD{5} = \blueE{135}\\ &16\\ \end{array}$  We have $16$ left. That's less than $\maroonD{27}$, so we're done dividing.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} {27}&\overline{\Big)421}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{270}&\purpleD{10}\\ &151\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{135}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{5}}\\ &\goldE{16}&\greenE{15}\\ \end{array}$  $\purpleD{10} + \purpleD{5}= \greenE{15}$, so our quotient is $\greenE{15}$, and our remainder is $\goldE{16}$.
$421 \div 27=\greenE{15}\text{ remainder }\goldE{16}$  [[☃ explanation 1]]

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $\maroonD{24}$ that may be useful:  - $\maroonD{24} \times 2 = 48$ - $\maroonD{24} \times 3 = 72$ - $\maroonD{24} \times 4 = 96$
$\maroonD{24} \times 40 $ is a little too large.    So, let's start by dividing $849$ into $\purpleD{30}\maroonD{\text{ twenty-fours}}$.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{24}&\overline{\Big)849}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{720}}&\purpleD{30}&\maroonD{24} \times \purpleD{30} = \blueE{720}\\ &129\\ \end{array}$  We have $129$ left. We know that $25\times 5=125$. So, let's try dividing $129$ into $5\maroonD{\text{ twenty-fours}}$.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{24}&\overline{\Big)849}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{720}&30\\ &129\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{120}}&\purpleD{5}&\maroonD{24} \times \purpleD{5} = \blueE{120}\\ &9\\ \end{array}$  We have $9$ left. That's less than $\maroonD{24}$, so we're done dividing.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} {24}&\overline{\Big)849}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{720}&\purpleD{30}\\ &129\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{120}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{5}}\\ &\goldE{9}&\greenE{35}\\ \end{array}$  $\purpleD{30} + \purpleD{5}= \greenE{35}$, so our quotient is $\greenE{35}$, and our remainder is $\goldE{9}$.
|| -: | :- $\greenE{35}$ | remainder $\goldE{9}$ ${24}\overline{\Big)849}$ |  [[☃ explanation 1]]

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $\maroonD{70}$ that may be useful:  - $\maroonD{70} \times 1 = 70$ - $\maroonD{70} \times 2 = 140$ - $\maroonD{70} \times 5 = 350$
$\maroonD{70} \times 20 $ is too large.    So, let's start by dividing $954$ into $\purpleD{10}\maroonD{\text{ seventies}}$.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{70}&\overline{\Big)954}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{700}}&\purpleD{10}&\maroonD{70} \times \purpleD{10} = \blueE{700}\\ &254\\ \end{array}$  We have $254$ left. We know that $7\times 3=21$. So, let's try dividing $254$ into $3\maroonD{\text{ seventies}}$.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{70}&\overline{\Big)954}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{700}&10\\ &254\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{210}}&\purpleD{3}&\maroonD{70} \times \purpleD{3} = \blueE{210}\\ &44\\ \end{array}$  We have $44$ left. That's less than $\maroonD{70}$, so we're done dividing.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} {70}&\overline{\Big)954}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{700}&\purpleD{10}\\ &254\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{210}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{3}}\\ &\goldE{44}&\greenE{13}\\ \end{array}$  $\purpleD{10} + \purpleD{3}= \greenE{13}$, so our quotient is $\greenE{13}$, and our remainder is $\goldE{44}$.
$954 \div 70=\greenE{13}\text{ remainder }\goldE{44}$  [[☃ explanation 1]]

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $\maroonD{25}$ that may be useful:  - $\maroonD{25} \times 4 = 100$ - $\maroonD{25} \times 6 = 150$ - $\maroonD{25} \times 8 = 200$
$\maroonD{25} \times 80 $ is a little too large.    So, let's start by dividing $1{,}675$ into $\purpleD{60}\maroonD{\text{ twenty-fives}}$.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{25}&\overline{\Big)1{,}675}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{1{,}500}}&\purpleD{60}&\maroonD{25} \times \purpleD{60} = \blueE{1{,}500}\\ &175\\ \end{array}$  We have $175$ left. That's a little more than $150$. So, let's try dividing $175$ into $7\maroonD{\text{ twenty-fives}}$.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{25}&\overline{\Big)1{,}675}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{1{,}500}&60\\ &175\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{175}}&\purpleD{7}&\maroonD{25} \times \purpleD{7} = \blueE{175}\\ &0\\ \end{array}$

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} {25}&\overline{\Big)1{,}675}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{1{,}500}&\purpleD{60}\\ &175\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{175}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{7}}\\ &\goldE{0}&\greenE{67}\\ \end{array}$  $\purpleD{60} + \purpleD{7}= \greenE{67}$, so our quotient is $\greenE{67}$, and we have no remainder.
|| -: | :- $\greenE{67}$ | remainder $\goldE{0}$ ${25}\overline{\Big)1{,}675}$ |  [[☃ explanation 1]]

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $\maroonD{96}$ that may be useful:  - $\maroonD{96} \times 2 = 192$ - $\maroonD{96} \times 3 = 288$ - $\maroonD{96} \times 5 = 480$
$\maroonD{96} \times 30$ is a little too large.    So, let's start by dividing $2{,}688$ into $\purpleD{20}\maroonD{\text{ ninety-sixes}}$.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{96}&\overline{\Big)2{,}688}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{1{,}920}}&\purpleD{20}&\maroonD{96} \times \purpleD{20} = \blueE{1{,}920}\\ &768\\ \end{array}$  We have $768$ left. We know that $100\times 7=700$. So, let's try dividing $768$ into $7\maroonD{\text{ ninety-sixes}}$.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{96}&\overline{\Big)2{,}688}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{1{,}920}&20\\ &768\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{672}}&\purpleD{7}&\maroonD{96} \times \purpleD{7} = \blueE{672}\\ &96\\ \end{array}$  We have $96$ left. So we can divide it into $1$ more $\maroonD{\text{ninety-sixes}}$.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{96}&\overline{\Big)2{,}688}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{1{,}920}&20\\ &768\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{672}&7\\ &96\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{96}}&\purpleD{1}&\maroonD{96} \times \purpleD{1} = \blueE{96}\\ &0\\ \end{array}$

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} {96}&\overline{\Big)2{,}688}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{1{,}920}&\purpleD{20}\\ &768\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{672}&\purpleD{7}\\ &96\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{96}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{1}}\\ &\goldE{0}&\greenE{28}\\ \end{array}$  $\purpleD{20} + \purpleD{7} + \purpleD{1}= \greenE{28}$, so our quotient is $\greenE{28}$, and we have no remainder.
$2{,}688 \div 96=\greenE{28}\text{ remainder }\goldE{0}$  [[☃ explanation 1]]

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $\maroonD{90}$ that may be useful:  - $\maroonD{90} \times 2 = 180$ - $\maroonD{90} \times 3 = 270$ - $\maroonD{90} \times 4 = 360$
$\maroonD{90} \times 40 $ is a little too large.    So, let's start by dividing $3{,}060$ into $\purpleD{30}\maroonD{\text{ nineties}}$.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{90}&\overline{\Big)3{,}060}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{2{,}700}}&\purpleD{30}&\maroonD{90} \times \purpleD{30} = \blueE{2{,}700}\\ &360\\ \end{array}$  We have $360$ left. So, let's try dividing $360$ into $4\maroonD{\text{ nineties}}$.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{90}&\overline{\Big)3{,}060}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{2{,}700}&30\\ &360\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{360}}&\purpleD{4}&\maroonD{90} \times \purpleD{4} = \blueE{360}\\ &0\\ \end{array}$

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} {90}&\overline{\Big)3{,}060}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{2{,}700}&\purpleD{30}\\ &360\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{360}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{4}}\\ &\goldE{0}&\greenE{34}\\ \end{array}$  $\purpleD{30} + \purpleD{4}= \greenE{34}$, so our quotient is $\greenE{34}$, and we have no remainder.
|| -: | :- $\greenE{34}$ | remainder $\goldE{0}$ ${90}\overline{\Big)3{,}060}$ |  [[☃ explanation 1]]

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $\maroonD{80}$ that may be useful:  - $\maroonD{80} \times 5 = 400$ - $\maroonD{80} \times 7 = 560$ - $\maroonD{80} \times 8 = 640$
$\maroonD{80} \times 70$ is close.    So, let's start by dividing $5{,}680$ into $\purpleD{70}\maroonD{\text{ eighties}}$.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{80}&\overline{\Big)5{,}680}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{5{,}600}}&\purpleD{70}&\maroonD{80} \times \purpleD{70} = \blueE{5{,}600}\\ &80\\ \end{array}$  We have $80$ left. So we can divide it into $1$ more $\maroonD{\text{eighty}}$.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{80}&\overline{\Big)5{,}680}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{5{,}600}&70\\ &80\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{80}}&\purpleD{1}&\maroonD{80} \times \purpleD{1} = \blueE{80}\\ &0\\ \end{array}$

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} {80}&\overline{\Big)5{,}680}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{5{,}600}&\purpleD{70}\\ &80\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{80}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{1}}\\ &\goldE{0}&\greenE{71}\\ \end{array}$  $\purpleD{70} + \purpleD{1}= \greenE{71}$, so our quotient is $\greenE{71}$, and we have no remainder.
$5{,}680 \div 80=\greenE{71}\text{ remainder }\goldE{0}$  [[☃ explanation 1]]

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $\maroonD{52}$ that may be useful:  - $\maroonD{52} \times 2 = 104$ - $\maroonD{52} \times 5 = 260$ - $\maroonD{52} \times 9 = 468$
$\maroonD{52} \times 90 $ is a little too small.    So, let's start by dividing $7{,}696$ into $\purpleD{100}\maroonD{\text{ fifty-twos}}$.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{52}&\overline{\Big)7{,}696}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{5{,}200}}&\purpleD{100}&\maroonD{52} \times \purpleD{100} = \blueE{5{,}200}\\ &2{,}496\\ \end{array}$  We have $2{,}496$ left. That's a little less than $2{,}600$. So, let's try dividing $2{,}496$ into $40\maroonD{\text{ fifty-twos}}$.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{52}&\overline{\Big)7{,}696}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{5{,}200}&100\\ &2{,}496\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{2{,}080}}&\purpleD{40}&\maroonD{52} \times \purpleD{40} = \blueE{2{,}080}\\ &416\\ \end{array}$  We have $416$ left. That's a little less than $468$. So, let's try dividing $416$ into $8\maroonD{\text{ fifty-twos}}$.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{52}&\overline{\Big)7{,}696}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{5{,}200}&100\\ &2{,}496\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{2{,}080}&40\\ &416\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{416}}&\purpleD{8}&\maroonD{52} \times \purpleD{8} = \blueE{416}\\ &0\\ \end{array}$

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} {52}&\overline{\Big)7{,}696}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{5{,}200}&\purpleD{100}\\ &2{,}496\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{2{,}080}&\purpleD{40}\\ &416\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{416}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{8}}\\ &\goldE{0}&\greenE{148}\\ \end{array}$  $\purpleD{100} + \purpleD{40} + \purpleD{8}= \greenE{148}$, so our quotient is $\greenE{148}$, and we have no remainder.
|| -: | :- $\greenE{148}$ | remainder $\goldE{0}$ ${52}\overline{\Big)7{,}696}$ |  [[☃ explanation 1]]

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $\maroonD{62}$ that may be useful:  - $\maroonD{62} \times 4 = 248$ - $\maroonD{62} \times 5 = 310$ - $\maroonD{62} \times 9 = 558$
$\maroonD{62} \times 90$ is a little too small.    So, let's start by dividing $8{,}370$ into $\purpleD{100}\maroonD{\text{ sixty-twos}}$.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{62}&\overline{\Big)8{,}370}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{6{,}200}}&\purpleD{100}&\maroonD{62} \times \purpleD{100} = \blueE{6{,}200}\\ &2{,}170\\ \end{array}$  We have $2{,}170$ left. That's a little less than $2{,}480$. So, let's try dividing $2{,}170$ into $30\maroonD{\text{ sixty-twos}}$.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{62}&\overline{\Big)8{,}370}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{6{,}200}&100\\ &2{,}170\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{1{,}860}}&\purpleD{30}&\maroonD{62} \times \purpleD{30} = \blueE{1860}\\ &310\\ \end{array}$  We have $310$ left. So, let's try dividing $310$ into $5\maroonD{\text{ sixty-twos}}$.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{62}&\overline{\Big)8{,}370}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{6{,}200}&100\\ &2{,}170\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{1{,}860}&30\\ &310\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{310}}&\purpleD{5}&\maroonD{62} \times \purpleD{5} = \blueE{310}\\ &0\\ \end{array}$

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} {62}&\overline{\Big)8{,}370}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{6{,}200}&\purpleD{100}\\ &2{,}170\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{1{,}860}&\purpleD{30}\\ &310\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{310}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{5}}\\ &\goldE{0}&\greenE{135}\\ \end{array}$  $\purpleD{100} + \purpleD{30} + \purpleD{5}= \greenE{135}$, so our quotient is $\greenE{135}$, and we have no remainder.
$8{,}370 \div 62=\greenE{135}\text{ remainder }\goldE{0}$  [[☃ explanation 1]]

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $\maroonD{20}$ that may be useful:  - $\maroonD{20} \times 2 = 40$ - $\maroonD{20} \times 3 = 60$ - $\maroonD{20} \times 5 = 100$
$\maroonD{20} \times 200 $ is too large.    So, let's start by dividing $2{,}311$ into $\purpleD{100}\maroonD{\text{ twenties}}$.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{20}&\overline{\Big)2{,}311}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{2{,}000}}&\purpleD{100}&\maroonD{20} \times \purpleD{100} = \blueE{2{,}000}\\ &311\\ \end{array}$  We have $311$ left. That's a little less than $400$. So, let's try dividing $311$ into $10\maroonD{\text{ twenties}}$.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{20}&\overline{\Big)2{,}311}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{2{,}000}&100\\ &311\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{200}}&\purpleD{10}&\maroonD{20} \times \purpleD{10} = \blueE{200}\\ &111\\ \end{array}$  We have $111$ left. That's a little more than $100$. So, let's try dividing $111$ into $5\maroonD{\text{ twenties}}$.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{20}&\overline{\Big)2{,}311}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{2{,}000}&100\\ &311\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{200}&10\\ &111\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{100}}&\purpleD{5}&\maroonD{20} \times \purpleD{5} = \blueE{100}\\ &11\\ \end{array}$  We have $11$ left. That's less than $\maroonD{20}$, so we're done dividing.

$\begin{array}{rr|rl} {20}&\overline{\Big)2{,}311}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{2{,}000}&\purpleD{100}\\ &311\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{200}&\purpleD{10}\\ &111\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{100}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{5}}\\ &\goldE{11}&\greenE{115}\\ \end{array}$  $\purpleD{100} + \purpleD{10} + \purpleD{5}= \greenE{115}$, so our quotient is $\greenE{115}$, and our remainder is $\goldE{11}$.
|| -: | :- $\greenE{115}$ | remainder $\goldE{11}$ ${20}\overline{\Big)2{,}311}$ |  [[☃ explanation 1]]
